descripcion: Researcher at the Allen Institute for Brain Science, studying the generation of cellular diversity in the brain. He leads the Seattle Alzheimer's Disease Cell Brain Atlas project. He has worked at the Center for Computational Biology at the Flatiron Institute and at the Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT. He developed nonparametric Bayesian methods to study individual cells using deep generative models for super-resolution imaging.

Mathematician, data scientist, and author of 'Weapons of Math Destruction'. Expert in algorithm auditing and AI ethics. Founder of ORCAA (O'Neil Risk Consulting & Algorithmic Auditing), a consulting firm dedicated to auditing algorithms and ensuring their ethical use. Has worked in the financial and academic industry, teaching at MIT and Barnard College. Her work focuses on the dangers of mathematical models in society.

Professor at the University of Rhode Island, specializing in nonparametric Bayesian models for spatiotemporal data. He earned his PhD in Statistics from Duke University and holds a Bachelor's and a Master's degree in Economics from Bocconi University. His research includes model mixtures, stochastic differential equations, and applications in environmental and social sciences

Professor at the University of the Andes. She completed her PhD in Applied Mathematics, focusing on post-quantum cryptography at the Technical University of Denmark (DTU). Her research areas include cryptography and coding theory. She has contributed to academic publications on attacks against cryptographic systems based on Reed-Solomon and McEliece codes.

Assistant Professor at Johns Hopkins University. A bioengineer from the National University of Entre Ríos, he earned his PhD in Computer Science from the Technion – Israel Institute of Technology. He has received awards for his work. Specializing in image processing, inverse problems, and machine learning, he has worked on sparse representation modeling and data reconstruction in biomedical signals.

Researcher at the University of Turin, modeling life histories using transformer models. Holds a PhD in Statistics from Lancaster University, where he developed Monte Carlo methods. Earned a Master's degree in Economics and Social Sciences from Bocconi University, specializing in nonparametric Bayesian models. First author in *Stat*, NeurIPS, and AISTATS on normalizing flows and Markov chain Monte Carlo.

PhD candidate in Mathematics at Queen Mary University of London under the supervision of Kevin Murphy and Alexander Shestopaloff. Develops learning algorithms for streaming data in changing environments, focusing on filtering techniques in non-stationary and misspecified contexts, such as online continual learning and signal extraction in high-dimensional environments with a low signal-to-noise ratio.

PhD candidate at the University of Montreal in the Mila laboratory under the supervision of Simon Lacoste-Julien. Her research areas include causality and machine learning. She holds a Bachelor's and a Master's degree from the University of Helsinki, where she worked under the supervision of Aapo Hyvärinen and Antti Hyttinen on ICA, and under the supervision of Maria Spiropulu and Maurizio Pierini at CERN.

PhD candidate in Statistical Sciences at UCL, working in the Fundamentals of Statistical Machine Learning group under the supervision of Jeremias Knoblauch and François-Xavier Briol. Develops robust generalized Bayesian methods applied to time series. He is supported by the Bloomberg Data Science PhD Fellowship. Previously, he worked at the Center for Mathematical Modeling at the University of Chile.

PhD candidate in Economics and Master in Quantitative Finance from Universidad del Rosario, Colombia. 20 years of university teaching experience in the field of applied mathematics for quantitative finance. Degree and Master's in Mathematics Education from Universidad Pedagógica Nacional. Committed to training highly skilled professionals.

Marine ecologist and science communicator. PhD in Biological Sciences from the National University of Córdoba. Researches Antarctic habitats and organism distribution using niche models, focusing on responses to climate change. Has collaborated with institutions in Spain, Germany, and Chile. Founder of Comunica al Natural and Executive Coordinator of Bayes Plurinacional.

Co-founder of Plurinational Bayes. Holds a degree in Social Anthropology and a PhD in Computer Science from the University of Buenos Aires. A professor in Data Science, Gustavo works in the software industry driving causal inference projects for multinational companies. He is the developer and maintainer of the skill estimator of the video games industry (TrueSkill Through Time) in Python, Julia, and R.
